description.narrative:
The project overall objective is to reduce risk of disaster by reducing the vulnerability of community and increase their capacity to cope with and mitigate the adverse effects of disasters ii. Specific Objective; The project specific objective is to strengthen emergency preparedness and response capacities of 6 target villages and other stakeholders in Paryan district of Panjshir province iii. Outcomes: - 6 communities, CHA team and provincial governments in Panjshir province are better prepared to minimize disaster risks and equipped to cope with shocks from disasters and conflict. - Advocacy at Paryan district of Panjshir province and national level on DRR issues leaded to an enhanced awareness on policy/implementation and reducing vulnerabilities of the community while facing disaster - Enhanced coordination (focusing on learning and sharing opportunities) among 6 targeted communities (VDCs and DDCs), CHA team and Panjshir provincial governments - Gender mainstreaming and Conflict transformation issues are integrated in to all humanitarian programmes/projects supported by Oxfam in Afghanistan. Project main activities:
- Conduct hazard, vulnerability and capacity (HVC) assessment with communities to prepare a disaster management plan (DMC) and increase awareness on vulnerably and capacities of communities. - Establishment of 12 village disaster committees (VDC) and build their capacity - Establishment of 2 disaster management committee (DMC) at two school level - Establish/ Strengthen District level Disaster Committees (DDC) and Provincial level Disaster Committees (PDCs) for better preparedness plans as well as for timely responses - Conduct DRR relevant trainings for VDC, DMC, DDC and other community members - Building capacity of provincial disaster management committee (PDC) - Raise and improve public awareness about different aspects of disaster management, response, gender/cultural/conflict issues and mobilize/orient on climate changes. - Develop district level contingency plan in order to institutionalize the preparedness and timely response and to make authorities accountable to people. - Distribution of first aid, search and rescue kit for 12 VDCs and 2 DMC - Support the vulnerable communities for mitigating activities e.g. facilitating participatory design and implementation of disaster risk reduction interventions toincrease resilience to economical and social shocks. - Implementation of 6 mitigation micro projects e.g. protection and retaining wall, gabion works etc

participating-org.narrative:
Co-ordination of Humanitarian Assistance (CHA) was founded in 1987 by a group of motivated Afghans involved in the provision of emergency relief to desperate populations in Western Afghanistan. The organisation quickly began to work on reconstruction andsustainable development. This took place in villages where hardly any developed had happened as a result of the war, and to support vulnerable groups in society, such as returning refugees. In its twenty six years of existence CHA has implemented projects in all sectors ofrelevance to rural development: agriculture, cattle raising, basic healthcare, and water supply, rural infrastructure (irrigation, roads and public buildings). CHA has developed approaches for every segment of the population, includingwomen. Its most important tool is working with the village council Shura or Community Development council (CDC), which kicks off processes at the local level.
CHA has been involved in improvement of formal and informal education system extensively. Through it#s Galaxy training centers, CHA provided training to girls in languages, science, computer, internet and fine arts to provide growth and development opportunities for young children. It also provides training for young adults preparing them for jobmarkets. It was a partner in large education programs such as Education Quality Improvement Program EQUIP and The building education support system for teachers (BESST) to support teachers so that they are able to deliver quality education for children.
Oxfam Novib has been supporting projects since 1992. In 1998 it began to support a wider program of providing services at the regional level. Vocational and supplementary education courses have also been given in several towns. This was often to supplement the many rural programs. CHA has regularly become involved in distributing emergency relief aid. Within the organisation the importance of such relief aid is subservient to that of long-term development; it is provided to save lives.
After 2001,CHAhas grown into one of the largest and most important national NGOs in Afghanistan working in the fields of rural development, education, health and is an important implementing partners of the Ministry of Rehabilitation, Reconstruction and Development (MRRD) in its community led rural development National Solidarity Program (NSP) and in the Afghan National Development Strategy (ANDS). CHA has actively and independently engaged in and initiated innovative projects like awareness raising through the radio,targeting the marginal poor, including women, in a program focusing on the improvement of the value chain of trade in natural plants, working with Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR), the establishment of an Afghan Education Watch, and more recently it hasincorporated popular campaigning in its intervention strategies.
In 2011, Oxfam Novib launched a pilot project - an innovative distance learning model that improves quality and accessibility of education for students, especially girls, within the frameworkof the vision of the Ministry of Education. CHA was an implementing partner for Oxfam Novib. The pilot phase was completed in Feb 2013 and was able to develop a model that improved the performance of girls and boys in 21 schools in Parwan and reducedropout rate. It was also very successful in improving teachers# capacity to deliver quality education in schools.
